title: Solid-State Transformer for Power Distribution Grid Based on a Hybrid Switched-Capacitor LLC-SRC Converter: Analysis, Design, and Experimentation
abstract: A solid-state transformer (SST) is being proposed for a distribution grid of 13.8 kV/380 V. The SST is based on the input-series output-parallel (ISOP) arrangement of twelve modules using the 1.2 kV SiC switches. The cost and losses analysis are discussed through a case study regarding the number of modules using the 1.2 kV and 1.7 kV SiC switches. The modules are composed of two stages: the first one is an AC-|AC| low-frequency rectifier and the second one is an |AC|-|AC| medium frequency Hybrid Switched-Capacitor LLC Series-Resonant Converter (HSCSRC). A single back-end |AC|-AC low-frequency inverter is employed to generate the low voltage AC output port of the SST. The switched capacitor ladder cell in the HSCSRC converter enables the reduction of the number of modules employed on the ISOP arrangement because the voltage stresses on the MV side's switches are halved, while the resonant stage increases the efficiency of the structure due to soft-switching on all the switches. Moreover, the front-end AC-|AC| and back-end |AC|-AC low-frequency converters enable the use of two-quadrant switches on the |AC|-|AC| HSCSRC converter, reducing the switch count on the medium frequency stage. The operating behavior and design methodology of the SST's modules are presented. A single module reduced scale prototype with the rated power of 1.67 kVA and an input voltage of 1.15 kV and an output voltage of 220 V is experimentally verified. The maximum efficiency is 97%.

I. INTRODUCTION
The fundamentals of electronic transformers were born
between 1968-1970, when William McMurray ﬁled his
patent on high frequency magnetic links on AC-AC power
electronics converters. The magnetic link is related to a
high/medium frequency transformer (HFT/MFT), which pro-
vides insulation and step-up or step-down voltage levels [1].
Additionally, the electronic transformer brought about new
functionalities when compared to the conventional bulky low
frequency transformer (LFT), such as: voltage regulation and

It can be seen that there are many acronyms for SSTs and,
in fact, for new readers, it may cause confusion. According
to [1] and [11], the basic idea of the SST is the voltage
level transformation by means of an HFT/MFT transformer,
in such way that it could lead to volume and weight savings
when compared to the power grid LFTs. However, other
authors [12] classify the SST as a three-port converter with
a high frequency magnetic link, where, regarding voltage,
the following characteristics of each port must be observed:
medium voltage AC, low voltage AC and low voltage DC.
In this way, the SST is able to interface with the power grid
with AC loads, energy storage and renewable energy systems.
Other authors [13] claim that an SST is compounded by
power electronics static converters that allow isolation among
medium voltage and low voltage systems through medium
frequency transformers. Regardless Brooks [2] named his
non-isolated converter an SST. It can be noted that all the
authors state that the galvanic isolation is a fundamental
characteristic of the SST. Thus, the key concepts of an SST
are summarized:
• Capacity to work with distribution grid voltage levels;
• Galvanic isolation through high/medium frequency
transformers;
• Controllability.
The SSTs can have multiple stages of energy conversion
and they can be classiﬁed in regard to the characteristic of
the DC link. Different types of AC-AC SSTs are illustrated
in Fig. 1, as presented in [11], [14].

It is well known that the commercial Silicon Carbide (SiC)
Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field Effect Transistor (MOS-
FET) devices are still limited to 1.7 kV , as well as in the case
of the Insulated-Gate Bipolar Transistor (IGBT) that remains
limited to 6.5 kV . Thus, in the medium voltage (MV) environ-
ment the series connection of semiconductors or converters is
mandatory to reduce the voltage stresses on devices. The MV
stages of the four types of SSTs in Fig. 1 can be implemented
as input-series output-parallel (ISOP) of nm modules.
The direct type AC-AC SST was classiﬁed as type I and it
uses matrix and/or cycle-converters, which result in a solution
without a DC link. The lack of energy storage devices, such
as a DC link, deteriorate the converter controllability. As a
result, the output frequency is equal to the input frequency,
there is no reactive compensation and neither output voltage
balancing due to single-phase fault of the MV grid. On the
other hand, in general, due to the reduced energy conversion
stages, the SST based on type I architecture results in higher
efﬁciency with minimized weight and volume [3], [15].
The SSTs based on type I architecture which have a
front-end low frequency (LF) rectiﬁer, without a DC link,
can be used to generate a unipolar |AC| voltage pulsating
at twice the grid frequency. As a result, the medium fre-
quency (MF) stage can be implemented with an |AC|-AC or
with an |AC|-|AC| converter, wherein, e.g., the two-quadrant
switches (TQSs) can be employed to reduce the total switch
count on the MV side. In regard to the SSTs based on
|AC|-|AC| converters, another back-end |AC|-AC LF inverter
is needed to unfold the output voltage of the MF stage. Then,
the SST’s output LV AC port is generated. The |AC| symbol
can be read as ‘‘rectiﬁed AC’’ in reference to unipolar voltage
that has a sinusoidal component. This nomenclature was
also used in [3], [16]–[18], and it highlights a differentiation
from the AC-DC converters, because on rectiﬁers the low
frequency components (100 Hz or 120 Hz) must be absorbed
by a bulky low frequency ﬁlter.
The type II architecture has a low voltage DC link (LVDC)
and two energy conversion stages, whose ﬁrst AC-DC stage is
an isolated front-end rectiﬁer and the second stage, a DC-AC
converter. According to [14], this kind of solution has the
following disadvantages: the 120 Hz voltage ripple on the
DC link; the volume occupied by the DC link in regard to
the total volume of the converter; and lower efﬁciency. The
type III architecture is similar to type II, both have two stages,
but the DC link is located on the medium voltage side and the
isolation is implemented in the back-end DC-AC converter.
Both type II and III have a higher degree of controllability
than type I, as the type II also enables an interface with
renewable energy by means of the LVDC link.
Lastly, the type IV has three energy conversion stages and
two DC links (MVDC and LVDC), which bring a higher
degree of freedom to the control, modulation and hardware
design, since there are a world of topologies that can be used
in each stage. However, when compared to the other types it
has higher complexity and cost, due to the large amount of
components and cascaded converters.
Recently, articles from big companies researching SST in
traction environments have been published (Siemens [19],
Bombardier [20], Alstom [21] and ABB [22]). The controlla-
bility and volume and weight savings are attractive attributes
of the SSTs for traction systems [13]. The SSTs in MV grid
applications remain as academic research (PES-ETHz [13],

The following advantages of an HSCSRC-based SST
can be highlighted: minimized switching losses on
Hard-switching or Soft-switching (e.g., in situations of partial
zero voltage switching (ZVS)) due to the reduced voltage
stress on the switches; natural balance between the divider
capacitors of the SC ladder cell due to the SC principle of
operation; reduction of the conduction losses (lower voltage

leading to the reduced electromagnetic interference (EMI)
problems; and lower differential mode insulation stresses in
the MFTs due to lower primary voltage (v Mx /2).
Another characteristic of the SST based on the HSCSRC
converter is the ﬂexibility in regard to the switch technology
that can be used in the power stage, instead of the usual
MOSFET-based SC topologies. This is possible because the
SC charge/discharge time constant (τ =RscCsc) is adjusted

source resistance of the MOSFETs switches on typical SC

IGBTs can be used to implement the switches S1,..,6, in the
way that a single module solution could be employed on the
distribution systems of 7.2 kV and 4.16 kV .

III. ANALYSIS OF THE |AC|-|AC| HSCSRC CONVERTER
The |AC|-|AC| HSCSRC converter shown in Fig. 3 was

synchronous rectiﬁcation. The switches S1,..,6 of the hybrid
SC ladder cell (MV side), as well as the switches So1,..,4
of the synchronous rectiﬁer (LV side), are controlled using
the pulse width modulation (PWM) with constant duty cycle
(50%) and invariable switching frequency (f s). The input and

VI. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
A three-phase SST ISOP architecture based on the HSCSRC
converter was proposed. The modules that are used in the
ISOP scheme, which are composed of the front-end AC-|AC|
rectiﬁer and the |AC|-|AC| HSCSRC converter, were ana-
lyzed, designed and veriﬁed, as well as an |AC|-AC unfold-
ing bridge was designed and veriﬁed for validation of the
single-phase and single-module reduced scale SST proof of
concept prototype. One of the main advantages of the pro-
posed SST based on the HSCSRC converter is the reduction
of the number of modules when comparing it to other SSTs
based on the FB and HB topologies, due to halving the voltage
stress across the switches on the MV side. Reduced module
count is very important regarding reliability and power den-
sity. Moreover, the voltage balance among the switches and
the divider capacitors are guaranteed through the switched
capacitor’s principle of operation. The simplest PWM modu-
lation with both constant duty cycle and switching frequency
is employed. Another advantage is the full or partial-ZVS
switching on the MV side’s switches, as shown in the exper-
imental results, along with the ZCS switching in all switches
of the HSCSRC converter, due to working near the resonance
frequency. This feature leads to a quiet converter regarding
electromagnetic compatibility. The proposed architecture is
suitable for line frequency in the range of 16 Hz to 400 Hz.
The theoretical analysis and design methodology were
validated through simulation and experimental results. The
SST presented a maximum efﬁciency of 97%, and the critical
point regarding efﬁciency was identiﬁed as the conduction
losses on the LV side’s switches. Thus, if higher efﬁciency
is needed, the switches with lower Rds resistances must be
employed in the synchronous rectiﬁer, or even use switches
in parallel connection, expecting cost increase. The proposed
design methodology enables the free variation of the switch-
ing frequency in the MFT transformer’s design stage, respect-
ing the minimum switching frequency found regarding the
design speciﬁcations. This enables an optimum design of the
MFT transformer, which is the heart of the proposed SST.
Thus, the SC ladder cell’s components were designed related
to the fsτ parameter, input power factor, and the losses in
the Rsc resistor. That resistor is purposely added to a series
connection with the Csc capacitor for a suitable design of
the operation mode of the switched capacitor (the PC mode).
The case study presented in the design methodology section
has shown that the 1.2 kV SiC MOSFET is suitable for the
proposed distribution grid application, regarding cost and
efﬁciency when compared to the 1.7 kV SiC technology. Even
when employing a higher number of modules, the solution
with twelve modules using the 1.2 kV SiC switches is bet-
ter than the case with nine modules employing the 1.7 kV
switches, because it leads to similar losses with lower costs
(43% lower).

interests include switched-capacitor converters,
soft-switching, resonant converters, solid-state transformers, high voltage
auxiliary power supplies, and modeling and manufacture techniques of
medium voltage and medium frequency transformers.
